topic.title: Customize to Render CGM Images (Experimental Support)

keywords.indexterm: XML documentsAuthor Mode editingImage renderingCGM images
CGM image rendering in Author mode

body.p: provides experimental support for CGM 1.0 images. To allow the rendering of CGM images in Author mode, go to and follow the instructions.follow this procedure:

ol.li: Go to Help Install new add-ons to open an add-on selection dialog box.
Select --ALL AVAILABLE SITES-- from the drop-down menu.
Select CGM Form support plugin and click Next.
Select the I accept all terms of the end user license agreement option and click Finish.

Restart the application.
Result: You should be able to see CGM images in Author mode.

section.title: Alternate Method for ISOView Active X Component
section.note: This support will only work on 32 bit versions of .
section.p: If you already have the ISOView Active X component for Internet Explorer installed, you may want to use it to render CGM images instead of the components provided in the plugin described above.

To use your existing ISOView Active X component to render CCM images, follow these steps:
Go to Help Install new add-ons to open an add-on selection dialog box.
Select --ALL AVAILABLE SITES-- from the drop-down menu.
Select CGM Form control (Active X-based) plugin and click Next.
Select the I accept all terms of the end user license agreement option and click Finish.
Restart the application.
The CGM Form Control plugin automatically renders CGM files in DITA, DocBook, and XHTML, so for those frameworks, this step is not necessary. For frameworks other than DITA, DocBook, or XHTML, modify your CSS according to your particular framework.
If you have an XML: <image href="MyCGMFile.cgm"/>
You need a CSS rule like this:image[href$=".cgm"], image[href$=".CGM"]{ content: oxy_editor( saHeavyFormControlClassName , "com.oxygenxml.activex.fctrl.ActiveXFormControl", href, oxy_url(oxy_base-uri() , attr(href))); } You should be able to see CGM images in Author mode.
